Political Obligation in Historical Perspective
1. Political Obligation in Historical Perspective

The phrase “political obligation” is apparently no older
than T. H. Green’s Lectures on the Principles of Political
Obligation, delivered at Oxford University in 1879–80
(D’Entrèves, p. 3). The two words from which Green formed the
phrase are much older, of course, and he apparently thought that
combining them required no elaborate explanation or defense. In any
case, there was nothing novel about the problem Green addressed in his
lectures: “to discover the true ground or justification for
obedience to law” (Green 1986, p. 13). Sophocles raised this
problem in his play Antigone, first performed around 440 BCE,
and Plato’s Crito recounts Socrates’ philosophical response
to the problem, in the face of his own death, some forty years
later.
